Is it a ſin to covet riches when one ſuffers the contempt of the world by reaſon of poverty? yes coveting ambitiouſly is execrable, but having a heart open to embrace the deluſions of the Devil, that, that alore is damnable! then deteſtable Shipton look into the glaſs of thy infirmities, which are ſo many they almoſt work a deſpair in me to cry peccavi •
yet have we not powers above that, over hels prevalency are predominant? then will I cleave to them! but is it not too late? ſooner I confeſs would have been better! but ſurely a heart penitentially inclined is not contemptible! then Devil look to thy ſelf, thou thinkeſt I am thine, but thou ſhalt find ere long thou art deceived. From thee

l.hi: And all thy Helliſh Sciences I now regret,
Heaven will forgive if Hell I doe forget.

div.head: Scen fourth.
div.p: HA, ha, ha, how I laugh at a poor crew of ſimple ſinners who perſue temptation more then it does them: who will ſcruple to ſwear dam me, ſince 'tis Allamode? and who will avoide living vitiouſly admirable in this world though they purchaſe Hell in the next? witneſs poor Shipton whoſe Name ecchoes out admiration, to whom I have been a ſmall attendant, but for no ſmal wages, I ſerve for ſouls but here ſhe comes.

sp.speaker: Ship.
sp.p: Ha! heres my ſoul catcher! now all goodneſs be my aſſiſtance we'ome my Radamon, thou art come juſt in the nick to accompliſh an earneſt requeſt I have too thee?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Name it and 'tis granted.

sp.speaker: Ship.
sp.p: Do't and ile confirm thou art a miraculous Devil! by all the Helliſh conſpiracy thou ere waſt maſter of, I do conjure thee to empty the Sea and make me ſole commandreſs of all the riches therein lye expanded!

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Impudent Witch! what has in joyn'd thee to that arrogancy to deſire that which all the power Hell could ever boaſt off never was able yet to grant.

sp.speaker: Ship.
sp.p: So his nonperformance of
This ſhall be my plea: why Radamon go to the ſumme of our contract art thou not my ſervant.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Yes I have been but now come in my Maſters name to command thy ſoul.

sp.speaker: Ship.
sp.p: My ſoul, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Yes thy Soul witch doſt laugh.

sp.speaker: Ship.
sp.p: Yes & does defie thee, know vaunting Devil by hells inſtigation I have hitherto lead a vitious life I have now found out the way to virtue, which to follow I am ſo undeterminably inclin'd, that no temptations ſhall withdraw me from the perſeverance of ſo good a reſolution.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Conceited woman how doſt thou flatter thy ſelf with impoſsibilities: conſider thy innumerable frailties, conſider thy daily practiſe of Murder, Witchcraft, fatal Propheſies and what not that has merited hells endleſs torments: conſider theſe rightly, and thou wilt find they are ſo pondrous they will weigh down the thoughts of any true felicity.

sp.speaker: Ship.
sp.p: Delude me no more, begon and tell thy Maſter, Shipton walks in a path will make her truly happy by avoiding Hell.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Thou lyeſt, thou art mine, reſign thy ſelf to me and that preſently or ile raiſe hels fiery King himſelf withall his dreadful furies to drag thee to his ever burning pallace!

sp.speaker: Ship.
sp.p: Do, I dread them not.

p.hi: Junx elke tu tenon Emon potidoma on Andra.

div.stage: [Pluto with other devils with rakes enters]

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: The cauſe of this great help thou craves?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: See where ſhe ſtands with ſuch audacity Hell cannot ſhew the like precedent.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: Have you expreſt our commands.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Yes and ſhe ſcorns them.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: Shipton thou art mine.

sp.speaker: Ship.
sp.p: Yes and you can take me.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: Seize on her ſtraight.

div.stage: [The Devils poke with their rakes and cannot touch her]

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: What are you grown feeble? ile joyn my ſtrength!

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: What preſervative has ſhe got againſt our power?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Too ſure ſhe is ſheilded by thoſe powers above, to which ours is impotent!

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: We muſt uſe other means Shipton farewell,
Pluto ſtill hopes to ſee thee hang in Hell.

div.stage: Exit all Devils with horrid muſick.

sp.speaker: Ship.
sp.p: I muſt now then conclude this to be the laſt attempt, ſtill, ſtill, protect me ye

lg.l: — Powers Coeleſtial and ile impart,

l.hi: Your glorious Mercy with a thankful heart.

div.head: Scen. Fifth.
div.stage: Enter Sir Oliver and his man David.

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.p: Now David how thinkeſt thou of my cunning.

sp.speaker: Dav.
sp.p: Very well truly Sir, you have a brain ile, ſay that for you.

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.p: Poor Shiftwel it troubles me though. O me what a brave man he was, no meeting at the Horſe race, Cocking, Hunting, Shooting or Fowling at which Shiftwel was not a principal Gameſter, and companion for the Nobility.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I Sir he has paid deer for thoſe follies, and 'tis but juſtice that ſuch as ſoar above their pitch, and will not be warn'd by his example ſhould like him ſhare in the miſeries that wait upon it.

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.p: Thou ſayeſt right David, and I in pitty have for theſe few years lent him a helping hand to raiſe his fortunes, but now for my own ſelf intereſt ſake I muſt leave him, therefore David run and fetch my boots and bring them to the Inne, ile haſte before.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I am gone Sir.

div.stage: [Sir Oliver goes off. and comes on agen preſently.]
Mrs. Love free looking out at her Belcony.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Lovefree.
sp.p: Bleſs me, ſure that is my old Knight that creeps along ſo or my eye-ſight failes me!

div.stage: Enter Money lack in a Serjeants habit.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: I arreſt you Sir, by the name of Sir Oliver Whorehound.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.p: Ha! 'tis he and arreſted. I muſt down and know the event.

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.p: Arreſt me Sir at whoſe ſuit?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: At Mr. Shiftwells ſuit upon two actions, with two or three executions which ſhall grinde you to powder when I have you in the Counter.

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.p: At Mr. Shiftwells ſuite, thou doſt belye him Varlet, he I dare lay will weep when he heres on't.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Yes like a Milſtone.

div.p: See where he comes you had beſt tell him ſo.

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.p: Nephew Shiftwel you are come moſt opportunely to free me from this Band • g. I know you gave no way to it nor had you any reaſon ſo to do.

sp.speaker: Mrs. L • .
sp.p: Bleſs me who do I ſee; Shiftwell is thy Name? O deceitful man!

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: Are you a Serjeant acquainted with the danger of a reſcue, yet ſtand here prating in the open ſtreets, the Counters ſure a ſafer place to parley in.

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.p: Your reaſon for this diſgrace to me?

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: 'Tis but juſtice in me. The reaſon you ſhall know hereafter.

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.p: Pray here me ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: Whilſt I like the adder ſtop my ears, or did I liſten, though you ſpake with the tongue of Angels I am not to be altered.

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.p: Pray make me ſenſible of the offence I have done, if it be any, and I will make the beſt of my eſtate to end the difference.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Love.
sp.p: How does my heart now pant bewteen Hope and fear, to know the period of this buſineſs,

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p:
He ſhew you ſome mercy which is this. That I will not torure you with falſe hopes, but make you know what you ſhall truſt
too: I have ſeiz'd upon your eſtate already, yet that ſhall not ſuff •… therefore Serjeant do your duty: yet ſtay Sir Oliver, I have conditions to propoſe, upon which Ile free you.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Sir I have been at the Inne and finding you not there came back to look you.

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.p: My journies ſtopt now David, Mr Shiftwell you may propoſe but I imagine the next Tavern, or ſome other place might be more convenient.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: With all my heart lets to the next Tavern, go ſend for two or three friends and diſcourſe of it there at large.

div.stage: Exit Sir Ol. Mo. and Shift.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Ha! a Serjeant on my maſters back, Shiftwel has napt him, now all will out as ile go hear.

sp.speaker: Mrs Love.
sp.p: Now is my ſhame as evident as day light, O unfortunate woman! that I ſhould have the ill-luck above all other men to meet with him, that I fear I ſhall find more then an honeſt man: but come what will, I muſt follow and in my Knights cauſe outlook the world with confidence.

div.stage: Sir Oliver. Shiftwel. Moneylack David and a Scrivener, Shiftwelis wife Maria and Sir Olivers wife apart as in another room.

sp.speaker: Shifs.
sp.p: Now Scrievener read the propoſitions.

sp.speaker: Scriev.
sp.p: That for the injury deſigned to Mr. Shiftwell you will freely give him a hundred pounds yearly during his life, and after his deceaſe to Maria.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Ha! to Maria, I can't conceive the reaſon, but ile be ſilenced till the future.

sp.speaker: Scriev.
sp.p: Secondly to make Mr. Shiftwels wife joynture a hundred pounds per annum more during her life, and laſtly to keep his wife and familie twelve years, and if at the twelve years end you intend to leave them fairly to give a quarters warning.

div.p: Heres one ſaies no to that but the reſt for your freedome Sir Oliver I muſt conſent too.

stage.hi: pu •… o • her ma • k and ſcarf

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: Ha! my dear wife.

sp.speaker: Sir Ol. W.
sp.p: You have been a hopeful husband, but blame me not if I have paid you in your coyn.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: I am amazed.

sp.speaker: Sir Ol. W.
sp.p: Nay ſtare not Mr Frankfort that was pretended, you and I have been a little better acquainted, but not with a thought that your wife and my husband were ſuch ſure bedfellowes

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.p: Well then wife I hope you'l pardon me.

sp.speaker: Sir Ol. W.
sp.p: I do and expect the ſame from you.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: Well I have loſt a good generous cuſtomer by the bargain, and 〈◊〉 be contented, but Sir Oliver you freely ſeal to theſe articles the laſt only omitted by your wives in junction.

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.p: Withall my heart, upon the giving me a bond for redelivery of my eſtate.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: That I will, only one thing more remayns: that upon Maria's acceptance of the perſon ſhe affects for her husband, you will pay down the marriage portion in your hands remaining.

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.p: Moſt freely.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: Then pray witneſſe the ſealing and delivery.

div.p: Now Sir Oliver what were have done we can't undoe, therefore Mr. Moneylace: diſcover your ſelf and accept my Siſter Maria for your wife.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: And I accept him as my only happineſs.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Deareſt Lady you have raiſed me to a joy beyond my thoughts may heaven requite you for your kindneſs, and I wear out my life to do you ſervice.

sp.speaker: Sir Ol.
sp.p: Bleſs me here are wonders in ridles.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Sir Oliver I muſt crave your pardon for my rudeneſs.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: There is a general pardon granted, and now good wife lets ſee how our ends will meet agen.

sp.speaker: Sh. W.
sp.p: I accept thee freely.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: Then we are all friends.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: I arreſt you Sir.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Arreſt him Villain?

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: Pray Brother with bold a little, at whoſe ſuit?

div.p: At this Gentlemans.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Then Ile end all. My noble Uncle!

sp.speaker: Scra.
sp.p: I have a requeſt to take my ſecurity for this Gentlemans debt, he is become my brother.

sp.speaker: Scra.
sp.p: Your Brother?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Even ſo ſir, to morrow I'm to marry this Gentlewoman his ſiſter: releaſe him therefore pray ſir for your nephews ſake.

sp.speaker: Scra.
sp.p: That I will Serjeant be gone I have ſatisfied you.

div.p: And pray Gentlemen pardon my ignorance of all theſe proceedings and Nephew I wiſh you much happineſs.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: I thank you Sir, come brother now to make all friends.

sp.speaker: Ship.
sp.p: Now lets in and drink each others health in

lg.l: Sack which the Gods did Nectar call,

l.hi: So end our mirth in a high Festival.

div.head: Scene Ult.
div.stage: Enter Radamon apparelled like a Gentleman and Shiptons Maid with a pu • ſe of Gold in her hand.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: TO be ſure ſir the next Nap ſhe takes if I get not the jewel ab • ut her Neck from her: I dare promiſe to give you your purſe of gold agen, and that would go a little againſt my conſcience.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Be very vigilant and fail not, then ile make thee Miſtres of all I have promiſed thee.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Eſpecially for my having you ſir for my Husband.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: O I can't avoid that, I love thee too well my pritty ſmug face,

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: I thank you ſir.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: But I may ſtay thee too long, thou maiſt miſs an oppotunity: fail not to meet at the place I've appointed thee.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Truly ſir I will not,

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Sure this plot cannot fail, which that it may not

l.hi: Ile to all my charming conſpiraces Will bend,

lg.l: Shipton thou wilt hardly ſhun Hell in the end.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p:
Now let me conſider of the preferment that will quickly fall upon me, muſt I that have been obeyſive to an old womans humour become a Miſtris of command: muſt I that have ſcoulded, nay many times ſcufled for a penny, become Miſtris of a purſe of Gold? muſt I that have many times ſtole out in an even to kiſſe an Hoſtler, be embraced by a Gentleman, a handſome Gentleman; with a fine head of hair, neat body, ſtraight leg, nay and another pritty property worth all the reſt, and then thou art fitted for a Husband Abigal ile warrant thee. But I have heard our next neighbour goody Belch often complain of her Husbands beating her, but I ſaith ile pummel my
Gentleman if he beats me, but let me ſee, I muſt finde out a gate to carry out my Gentility, will this Gate do?
No it ſents too much of the ſerving maid, well then ſo
No I ſtretch out my belly too much and that needs not, for my Huſband does promiſe to get me with child quickly, and then e'faith my belly will ſtretch out it ſelf.
O this then will ſerve

sp.speaker: Ship.
sp.p: Ha! huswife is this your making haſte when I ſend you of an errand, what purſe have you got there? and what fine Gentleman are you to have for your Husband?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Pray Miſtris be not angry and on my bended knees I will relate the ſtory.

sp.speaker: Ship.
sp.p: Ceaſe that Ceremony and begin.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Why truly forſooth at the Corner of this field I met with a very Gallant Gentleman who gave me this purſe of gold, and promiſed to morrow morn to marry me, if I would but ſteal that jewel about your Neck from you.

sp.speaker: Ship.
sp.p: Indeed forſooth, well open your purſe and tell your gold.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: O heaven Miſtris 'tis all ſtones and dirt,

sp.speaker: Ship.
sp.p: Yes and he that gave it thee a Devil, for none elſe would inſinuate thee to rob me of this jemne of my true happineſs.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: A Devil! O how I find my fears encreaſe.

sp.speaker: Ship.
sp.p: Go in Girle ile follow and protect thee.

sp.speaker: Ship.
sp.p: This was Radamons device: but arm me ſtill ye powers devine that no Devils inſtigation does betray me: protect me even now for I find a ſudden ſlumber ſeizes me.

stage.hi: [Soft Muſick and in Angel deſcends with a Book.]
stage.l: Shipton deſpair not but in hope grow ſtrong.

l.hi: Thou ſhalt find Mercy though thou haſt done wrong!
Read ore this book and in it thou ſhalt find
The ſumme of thy deſire to free thy mind.
From fear, thy ſoul ſecure from harm
Of any Devils! 'tis a happy charme!

div.p: Ha! what's this a book? the cover bears the type of innocence, ile ok in it.
Shipton

l.hi: In thy ſorrows be not drown'd
From above thou hast mercy found:
Think not repentance comes too late
If 'tis unfeigned thou art fortunate!
And though the Devil does endeavour
To entrap thy ſinful ſoul, yet never
Yeild, but his attempt reſiſt,
And he his ſuit will ſoon deſiſt.

div.p: O endleſs comfort! now attempt what you can proud Devils, but •… s! what noiſe is this?
div.stage: Enter Pluto and all the Devils.

l.hi: Well your buſineſs now? you ſee I do not quake
That ere while made you and your Furies ſhake.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: Wee know thy power and thy magick skill, and for the entreaſe of the ſame, we preſent thee with this paper wherein is a ſpell of Propheſie to fore tell of what was, what is, and whats to come. In his paper there is another ſpell powerful to command any ſpirit of w at nature ſoever,

sp.speaker: Skip.
sp.p: Well I accept your preſents but ſpurn at your ſociety, all your emptations are airy and too weak to beſiedge my fortyfied ſoul.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.p: Was ever Devil gull d ſo:

l.hi: VVell lets deſcend and all Hell ſhall howl

lg.l: This full fortnight for loſſe of Shiptons ſoul.

sp.speaker: Ship.
sp.p: So let them roare.

l.hi: VVhilſt I do all their Helliſh Acts deſpiſe
The higher powers make me truly wiſe.

div.head: The Epilogue.
div.l: NOw you have taſted of our homely chear,
Pray tell us how you like it: was it dere?
Or elſe where lay the fault? pray gallants tell,
If't did diſpleaſe t'was ill, if not 'twas well,
But may the Ladies ſmile on't i'm ſure then,
'Twill be approved off by the Gentlemen!
So pleaſing both we are in hopes we may
Expect your company another day.

div.head: An after Epilogue ſpoken by Shipton.
div.l: IV'e ſcap't the Devil but I fear you moſt,
If your frowns appear poor Shiptons loſt▪
But now I look agen, methinks I ſpy
A gentle pardon in each gratious eye.
Viſit me oftner and in time you'l ſee
Poor Shipton may deſerve your plaudite.
